snippet: Aaron Alexis, who the police say killed 12 people at the Washington Navy Yard, had a history of mental health problems and firearm arrests that fell below a level that would have raised red flags.
abstract: Washington Navy Yard gunman Aaron Alexis, former Navy reservist who as an independent contractor serviced Navy computers, had a history of mental health problems and firearm arrests that fell below level that would have raised red flags; revelations raise questions about government's system for vetting people for security clearances, including thousands of contractors who help run nation's military and security systems.

byline.original: By TRIP GABRIEL, JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Manny Fernandez and Lauren D’Avolio from Fort Worth, Carl Hulse, Sarah Maslin Nir and Thom Shanker from Washington, Kirk Johnson from Seattle, and Erica Goode, Timothy Williams, Ariel Kaminer and Nate Schweber from New York.

lead_paragraph: Aaron Alexis, who the police say killed 12 people at the Washington Navy Yard, had a history of mental health problems and firearm arrests that fell below a level that would have raised red flags.

headline.main: Suspect’s Past Fell Just Short of Raising Alarm
headline.print_headline: Suspect’s Past Fell Just Short of Raising Alarm
